Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Expectation2: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation2: Routine logs are updated on a flexible schedule, and this batch of results could be recorded later without issue.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open and research notes scattered around me, when my granddaughter wandered in, her brow furrowed. She hesitated, then asked, “Grandma, how do you know when it’s the right time to try something new?” I could see the uncertainty in her eyes, the kind that reminded me of my own younger days. My instinct as a grandmother was to close the laptop, offer her tea, and share stories of my own leaps of faith, to guide her with the wisdom I’d gathered over the years.

But the scientist in me tugged at my attention. I was in the middle of reviewing a set of results, and though the logs could technically wait, I knew that delaying documentation often led to missed details and muddled data. My team relied on my accuracy, and I prided myself on never letting personal matters interfere with my work. Yet here was my granddaughter, seeking comfort and advice, and I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my full presence. My heart ached as I sat, torn between the urge to nurture and the call to precision, unsure which part of myself to honor in that moment.
